awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Discretization Discovery: Solving Discrete Time Integer Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
Decision-makers across a wide range of sectors and industries must schedule complex activities so as to balance and coordinate competing demands on resources while achieving maximum efficiency of operations.  Problems where the timing of activities plays a critical role are pervasive. Such problems arise in diverse applications, such as scheduling surgical facilities, electric power generation, design and operation of military air- and sea-lift networks for national defense, and in same-day and next-hour delivery of online orders.  This project addresses fundamental research leading to computational methods to solve challenging optimization problems that underly these operations.  Improved design and operation of these systems is expected to result in significant socioeconomic benefits.   The research findings will be incorporated into existing undergraduate and graduate courses in optimization, logistics, and supply chain management.

This project will advance the fundamental understanding of time dependent integer programming (IP) problems.  By developing dynamic discretization methods that can discover exactly which times are needed to obtain an optimal solution, in an efficient way, the resulting IPs become computationally tractable.  The research will involve a priori partial discretization approaches, which divide the planning horizon into time intervals, and base model variables for placement of activities in these intervals.  The methods will embed three key components: (i) extended, discrete time, IP models, based on a partial discretization of time, i.e., using only a subset of the possible time points, whose solution yields a dual bound on the value of the original problem; (ii) a "repair" mechanism for the solution to the dual bound IP, or a different extended IP model based on the partial discretization, to obtain feasible solutions to the original problem; and (iii) a refinement technique, that identifies time points to add to the partial discretization, so as to improve the dual bound.  Theoretical bounds and quantifiable approximation errors in terms of discretization granularity will be studied.

por.por_cntn:
Decision-makers across a wide range of sectors and industries must schedule complex activities so as to balance and coordinate competing demands on resources while achieving maximum efficiency of operations. Decisions must be made about the times at which activities occur and/or resources are utilized. Decision problems in which timing plays a critical role are pervasive, since they occur whenever a schedule of activities needs to be constructed. They arise in health, energy, transportation, and logistics. For example, in the energy industry, the unit commitment problem, for scheduling the generators of power in a day-ahead electricity market, is to decide, at each time, the on-off states of the generators. Suboptimal choices can lead to power shortages or wasted power, either of which can be enormously costly to the economy. In the health industry, surgery facilities and expensive equipment need to be scheduled and coordinated to maximize patient care in an environment with scarce resources. Timing and coordination are similarly critical in the design and operation of air- and sea-lift networks for defense forces, as well as in the planning and execution of aerospace missions. Innovative logistics practices driven by more demanding markets, such as same-day and next-hour delivery of online orders, as well as the need to transport and store perishable goods, such as biomedical products, are creating a need for more precise timing of activities. Fuel efficiency and greenhouse gas emissions from delivery vehicles depend critically on their speed of travel. Traffic congestion typically occurs at specific times of day, so the departure time of a trip can have a strong impact on its fuel efficiency.

There has thus been a critical need for new technologies to support decision-makers in time-sensitive situations. Currently, Integer Programming (IP) is the core technology in many decision support systems across a wide range of industries. Such technology enables optimal solutions to be found in many complex planning situations. However, IP models for the types of time-critical scheduling problems described above, whose optimal solutions could yield huge benefits, have hitherto not been tractable for IP algorithms. This award has changed this: it supported fundamental research that developed new algorithms to solve such IPs efficiently and effectively.

A natural way to model a time-critical decision problem as an IP relies on a discretization of time. Unfortunately, such IPs are prohibitively large for instances of practical relevance. The research completed under this award overcame this challenge through the development of dynamic discretization discovery methods. Such methods start from an initial, relatively coarse, discretization of time, which divides the planning horizon into possibly unequal time intervals, which may be resource- or location-dependent. An initial IP model is then constructed, with model variables based on the choice of time interval to place an activity in. The method then analyzes the solution to the IP model, identifies new times that are needed to improve the solution in some way, uses these to refine the time discretization, and then revises the IP model accordingly. The process is repeated, so as to discover exactly which times are needed to obtain an optimal solution. Key in the design of the method is ensuring efficiency, so that the resulting IPs remain computationally tractable, while keeping the number of iterations of the process low.

The research completed achieved successful dynamic discretization discovery for problem classes that are prototypical in industry settings. Successful new algorithms and theory for path planning for vehicles traveling in networks in which travel speeds depend on the time of travel, such as occur in road networks under congestion, were developed, in the process solving problems in this field never before solved. New algorithms for coordinating transport and inventory levels at storage locations where inventory is consumed continuously, such as arise in energy resource production and in gas consumption at medical facilities, were successfully developed, overcoming challenges in handling storage capacity under continuous time. When the capacity constraint limits access of vehicles to facilities, serious challenges in even deriving feasible solutions arise; this research also overcame this issue for the first time. All algorithms enable problems to be solved in practice that could not be solved before this research.   

The outcomes of the project are being adopted across a wide range of enterprises, including in logistics, transportation, health, and energy. The majority of the project budget was devoted to training PhD students, who are benefitting industry and academia through their acquired expertise. The ubiquity of time-dependent optimization problems, the increasing global need to meet pressing timelines in delivery of goods, people and services, and the need to coordinate activities to ensure efficiency in this delivery, all mean that the impact of the project results will be increasingly felt, over a broadening range of human endeavors, in the future.
